p: The inhalation of rosemary oil in 144 healthy volunteers induced subjective effects on mood as well as objective effects on cognitive performance ( 43). In another study, the aroma of rosemary oil improved performance in exam students by enhancing free radical scavenging activity and decreasing cortisol levels ( 44). In a study by Pengelly et al. 2012, rosemary powder (750 mg), the dose nearest to the normal culinary consumption, showed positive influences on the speed of memory, the time taken to effectively regain information from both episodic and working memory, on 28 older adults (mean age, 75 years) which is a useful predictor of cognitive function during aging ( 45). These results point to the value of further studies on the effects of different doses of rosemary on memory and cognition over the longer period of time.
